Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Caudal Adjuvants in Pediatric Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive a caudal block with dexmedetomidine 1 μg/kg (Group D), morphine 30 μg/kg (Group M), or clonidine 1.5 μg/kg (Group C), along with 0.2% ropivacaine.

Participants.evidence: 63 children aged 1–6 years with ASA physical status I or II were enrolled. Conducted at a tertiary hospital in southern India.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive a caudal block with dexmedetomidine 1 μg/kg (Group D), morphine 30 μg/kg (Group M), or clonidine 1.5 μg/kg (Group C), along with 0.2% ropivacaine.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the efficacy of morphine, clonidine, and dexmedetomidine as adjuvants to 0.2% ropivacaine in caudal blocks for extending postoperative analgesia in children undergoing infraumbilical surgeries.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the duration of analgesia, defined as the time until the first rescue analgesic was required.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 63 children aged 1–6 years with ASA physical status I or II were enrolled.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median duration of analgesia was 380 minutes for Group D, 360 minutes for Group C, and 405 minutes for Group M, with no statistically significant difference (P = 0.843).

Harms.evidence: Total perioperative opioid use and side effects were similar across groups. Intraoperative hypotension occurred in 43.5% of Group D, 27.8% of Group C, and 22.7% of Group M (P = 0.299). Postoperative nausea and vomiting were observed in 21.7% of Group D, 5.6% of Group C, and 18.2% of Group M (P = 0.382).
